INVESTMENT SUMMARY 
 
Investment Proposal  Investment in the ASEAN China Investment Fund II of up to $25 
million or 25% of the fund's total share capital, whichever is less. 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will not be the single largest 
investor in the fund. 
   
Classification   Targeting classification: General intervention 
  Sector (subsectors): Finance (investment funds, small and 
medium-sized enterprise [SME] finance and leasing, finance 
sector development) 
Themes (subthemes): Regional cooperation and integration (trade 
and investments), economic growth (widening access to markets 
and economic opportunities), private sector development 
(private sector investment)  
Location impact: Regional (low) 
   
Environmental and  Environment:      FI (financial intermediary) 
Social Safeguards  Involuntary Resettlement:  C

Investment Description  The fund will seek to provide appreciation of capital through private 
equity  investments  in  growth-oriented  SMEs  in  Association  of 
Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  countries  and  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC), particularly companies that can benefit 
from the region's expanding trade and economic integration. The 
fund  is  targeting  capital  commitments  of  $250  million  and  is 
organized as a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership. The 
fund is managed by UOB Capital Partners (the fund manager), 
which is assisted by UOB Venture Management ([UOBVM], the 
fund advisor). The fund will have a term of 8 years from its final 
closing. 
   
Impact, Outcome, and  The impact of the project will be a contribution to the regional trade 
Benefits  and  investment  among  ASEAN  countries  and  between  ASEAN 
countries and the PRC, and the demonstration effect of the fund 
leading to improved private capital flows to the SME sector in ADB 
DMCs. 
 
The outcome of the project will be improved access to finance 
resulting in increased SME activity in ADB developing member 
countries (DMCs). 
 
The output of the project will be the establishment of the fund as 
planned  in  this  proposal  to  identify,  screen,  and  evaluate 
investment opportunities, and make financially viable investments 
over time.

ii     
 
Risks and Mitigating  This investment will be subject to risks normally associated with 
Measures  equity  investments  of  this  nature  such  as:  (i)  suitability  of 
investment strategy; (ii) risks from competition with other funds; (iii) 
risks from insufficient management resources; (iv) risk associated 
with potential conflicts of interest; (v) risks from difficulty in exiting 
investment positions; (vi) currency risks;  (vii) political, economic 
and  social  risks;  (viii)  risks  associated  with  accounting  and 
disclosure  standards  that  do  not  accord  with  international 
standards;  and  (ix)  risks  from  changing  legal  and  regulatory 
environments.    ADB  has  considered  or  defined  the  necessary 
steps to address and mitigate these risks. 
   
Justification / ADB  ADB's support to this transaction is justified with a range of value 
Value-Added  additions to the fund. First, ADB's investment will act as a catalyst 
in raising funds. As a result of the current challenging fund raising 
environment, the fund manager is finding it difficult to raise the 
required capital for this fund. ADB's participation will send a strong 
signal  to  the  market  and  enable  the  fund  to  reach  its  desired 
capitalization. Second, ADB’s new sets of environment and social 
safeguard policies and procedures will be crucial in enriching the 
governance  of  the  fund.  These  policies  will  enable  the  fund 
manager to integrate best practices with regard to environmental 
and social standards in the investee SMEs in the DMCs. Third, 
ADB can provide additional support to the fund in understanding 
the regional market dynamics through ADB’s multifaceted links to 
various governments and institutions in the region. This will enable 
the fund manager to appropriately assess future engagements and 
arrive at an accurate and informed investment decision.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
equity investment in the ASEAN China Investment Fund II of up to $25 million or 25% of the 
fund's total share capital, whichever is less.  
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
A.  Economic and Sector Background 
2.  Over  the  past  decade,1 Asia  has  become  an  increasingly  attractive  destination  for 
investors  due  to  the  region’s  rapid  economic  growth,  comprehensive  reforms,  structural 
changes, and increasing globalization.2 However, as a result of the recent economic crisis, a 
number of the export-oriented Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN)3 economies 
have been hit hard, and their recovery has been slow. There is still considerable uncertainty 
about the duration of the economic slowdown and the extent to which Asia will be affected.  
 
3.  Asia has become more deeply integrated with global financial markets. As a result of the 
financial crisis, such integration has led to the tightening of Asian credit markets. In assessing 
the current situation, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Asian Development Outlook 20094 
cites that, considering its robust domestic demand, the People's Republic of China (PRC) has 
an important role in the region's recovery. The impact of this crisis to Asia can still be cushioned 
by enhancing trade flow between the PRC and the smaller economies in the region. In light of 
this scenario, the fund's strategy of investing in companies that will promote greater economic 
and trade links between ASEAN and the PRC becomes even more important.  
 
4.  Status  of  ASEAN–PRC  economic  relations. Regional cooperation and integration 
among its member and neighboring countries is one of the crosscutting strategic themes of 
ASEAN. The association is focused on promoting regional growth and economic integration, 
including economic and policy reforms and investment incentives. ASEAN also facilitates fast-
track trade liberalization within the ASEAN free trade area. Appendix 2 gives key economic 
features of ASEAN and the PRC. 
 
5.  The PRC is increasingly becoming a major economic power in the region. It has twice 
the land area of ASEAN, it is roughly 2.3 times larger than ASEAN in terms of population, and 
its  gross  domestic  product  is  approximately  2.25  times  that  of  ASEAN.  Also,  the  PRC's 
economic  liberalization  and  its  membership  in  the  World  Trade  Organization  are  further 
enhancing ASEAN–PRC trade and investment opportunities. Trade between ASEAN and the 
PRC increased by 22 times between 1991 and 2008, with the volume reaching $193 billion in 
2008.5   
 
6.  In 2008, the PRC became the third-largest trading partner of ASEAN, behind Japan and 
the European Union, and overtook the United States, which was fourth.4 This statistical finding 
shows the increased exposure and significance of the PRC in the ASEAN trade area. Exploiting

7.  ASEAN–PRC agreement on trade has evolved over the years. In November 2002, the 
framework agreement for the ASEAN–PRC free trade area was signed at the eighth ASEAN 
summit meeting in Cambodia. The framework agreement committed ASEAN and the PRC to 
negotiate the liberalization and promotion of trade in goods and services between them. An 
announcement on bilateral investment was released on 15 August 2009; it stated that the PRC 
commerce minister, Chen Deming, and the economic ministers from 10 ASEAN members 
signed the ASEAN–China Investment Agreement during the 41st ASEAN Economic Ministers 
Meeting. The signing of the investment agreement, together with the previously signed PRC–
ASEAN agreements of the trade in goods and services, completed the negotiation process of a 
PRC–ASEAN free trade area, which started on 1 January 2010. This agreement envisions "to 
promote  investment  flows  and  to  create  liberal,  facilitative,  transparent  and  competitive 
investment regimes" for both ASEAN and the PRC through defined mechanisms such as, 
among other things, improving the transparency of investment rules conducive to increased 
investment flows.6 
 
B.  Investment Identification and Description 
8.  In 2004, ADB made a $15 million investment in the ASEAN China Investment Fund 
(ACIF I).7 ADB has thus known the fund manager for over 5 years and has developed a close 
relationship with the team through this investment. There are other regional funds in existence 
that could also represent worthy investment targets. However, based on the alignment of this 
fund with ADB's regional trade and integration strategies, and on the positive economic and 
development  outcomes  of  ACIF  I  investment,  ADB  feels  confident  contemplating  ongoing 
support for a fund manager that ADB helped to promote before.  
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
9.  Strategy 2020 identifies private sector development as a key driver of change, and 
finance sector development as one of five core specializations that support ADB’s agenda.8 
Strategy 2020 focuses on three strategic priorities: inclusive economic growth, environmentally 
sustainable  development,  and  regional  integration.  In  addition,  Strategy  2020  emphasizes 
private  sector  development  as  a  means  to  achieve  sustainable  and  inclusive  growth.  The 
relationship of the fund to each of the priorities and drivers of change is summarized as follows: 
 
1.  Strategy 2020 Priorities 
(i)  Inclusive  economic  growth.  The  fund  provides  much-needed  growth 
capital for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in ASEAN and the 
PRC. Such companies play a vital role in generating employment and 
supporting inclusive economic growth.

(ii)  Environmentally  sustainable  development.  The  fund  systematically

social  guidelines,  and  for  compliance  with  corporate  governance  best 
practices. In addition, the fund introduces investee companies to such 
guidelines and standards, as well as compliance procedures. 
 
(iii)  Regional  integration.  The  fund  provides  growth  capital  to  SMEs  in 
ASEAN  and  the  PRC,  particularly  those  that  can  benefit  from  the 
continuing expansion of regional trade and investment between ASEAN 
member  states  and  the  PRC,  and  their  respective  overseas  trading 
partners. The fund enables the investee companies to list their shares on 
a regional stock exchange, thus contributing to regional integration as well 
as capital markets development. 
 
2.  Strategy 2020 Drivers of Change  
(i)  Private sector operations. The fund provides a mechanism to attract 
much-needed responsible and sustainable private investment to ASEAN 
and the PRC. The fund catalyzes investment on two levels: firstly, through 
direct investment in private companies, and secondly, by helping such 
companies to tap the public capital markets, typically by means of a stock 
exchange listing. 
 
(ii)  Gender equity. The fund is expected to be an important source of job 
creation for women, particularly in SMEs. The fund monitors the labor 
practices and conditions of its investee companies. Such monitoring helps 
to  detect  and  correct  instances  of  gender-based  discrimination  and/or 
harassment (both of which are major impediments to hiring and retaining 
employees,  particularly  women,  in  the  workforce),  and  ensure  that 
investee companies do not use child labor. 
 
(iii)  Partnerships. The fund provides a mechanism for ADB to partner with 
like-minded investors from both the private and public sectors, who seek 
to promote responsible and sustainable private enterprise development in 
ASEAN and the PRC. 
 
10.  Finally, this project aligns well with ADB's prior investment with the fund manager to 
promote SME lending and the above-mentioned ADB sector strategies, and represents a good 
fit for ADB's involvement. 
 
D.  Development Impact 
11.  In this transaction, ADB's investment in the fund is intended in the long term to help 
increase regional trade, economic growth, and private sector development in Asia. This set of 
linkages, as detailed in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1), can be understood 
as follows: 
 
(i)  Impact. The impact of the project will be a contribution to regional trade and 
investment among ASEAN countries and between ASEAN countries and the

4 
PRC, and the demonstration effect of the fund leading to improved private capital 
flows to the SME sector in ADB DMCs. 
 
(ii)  Outcome.  The  outcome  of  the  project  will  be  improved  access  to  finance 
resulting  in  increased  SME  activity  in  ADB  developing  member  countries 
(DMCs).   
 
(iii)  Output.  The  output  of  the  project  will  be  the  establishment  of  the  fund  as 
planned  in  this  proposal  to  identify,  screen,  and  evaluate  investment 
opportunities, and make financially viable investments over time.  
 
 
12.  The project will promote development in a number of ways, including (i) promoting closer 
economic and trade links between ASEAN and the PRC; (ii) developing SMEs, which will 
benefit from such links; (iii) deepening regional capital markets; (iv) helping to promote balanced 
development and reduce the risks associated with overdependence on a limited number of 
traditional  export  markets;  (v)  transforming  investee  companies  by  helping  them  to  adopt 
financially prudent and sustainable business practices and internationally accepted standards; 
and (vi) catalyzing the mobilization of long-term capital from institutional investors from both 
within  and  outside  the  region.  See  Appendix  8  for  Environmental  and  Social  Governance 
Improvements of ACIF I Portfolio Companies.  
 
III.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY  
A.  Sponsor and Ownership 
13.  Sponsor. The United Overseas Bank (UOB) is the fund sponsor and is the lead investor 
with a capital commitment of $30 million. UOB was incorporated in August 1935 as the United 
Chinese Bank and has grown over the last 73 years. Through a series of acquisitions, it became 
a leading bank in Singapore, with banking subsidiaries in the region. Today the UOB has a 
network of over 500 offices in 18 countries and territories in Asia and the Pacific, Western 
Europe, and North America. UOB provides a wide range of financial services through its global 
network  of  branches  and/or  offices  and  subsidiaries—personal  financial  services,  private 
banking,  trust  services,  commercial  and  corporate  banking,  investment  banking,  corporate 
finance,  capital  market  activities,  treasury  services,  asset  management,  venture  capital 
management, general insurance, and life insurance. UOB is rated among the world's top banks 
by Moody's Investors Service, receiving ratings as of 31 December 2007 of B for financial 
strength, Aa1 for long-term deposits, and Prime-1 for short-term deposits. As of 31 December 
2007, UOB had total assets of approximately $122 billion.  
 
14.  In 2007, UOB further expanded its operations in Asia. It received approval to incorporate 
the United Overseas Bank (China) in the PRC, and it also completed the acquisition of a 10% 
stake in the Southern Commercial Joint Stock Bank in Viet Nam. The core strengths of UOB lie 
in its market knowledge of Asia, consumer and SME banking expertise, and proven technology, 
risk management, and corporate governance framework. 
 
15.  Ownership. The fund will be owned by its investors (including ADB). Commitments 
and/or interests in the fund thus far include $30 million from UOB, a substantial commitment

5
from the China Development Bank (CDB), and up to $10 million from Proparco.9 Further fund 
investor commitment details are provided in Para. 33. 
 
B.  Governance Structure 
1.  Management  
16.  The fund will be managed by UOB Capital Partners (the fund manager). The fund 
manager is wholly owned by UOB Global Capital, a member of the UOB, and Westmount 
Pacific, an affiliate of Westmount Asset Management, a registered investment adviser in the 
United States. UOB Global Capital owns 70% of the fund manager and Westmount Pacific owns 
30%.  
 
17.  The fund manager will engage the UOB's wholly owned venture capital affiliate, UOB 
Venture Management (UOBVM) to provide specialized investment advisory services to the fund. 
UOBVM will be responsible for all investment and divestment activities of the fund. UOBVM has 
extensive private equity, venture capital, and direct business operating experience, as well as a 
demonstrated ability to operate effectively in the region's multicultural environment. Appendix 3 
provides the fund's structure and organizational relationships. 
 
2.  Corporate Governance 
18.  Board of directors. The fund manager will be governed by a board of directors. The 
initial directors of the fund manager will be Kie Cheong Chong, Kian-Wee Seah, Robert A. 
Berliner, David T. Goss, and Michael Landau. Appendix 4 provides the biographical data for the 
initial directors of the fund manager. 
 
19.  Advisory board. The fund will have an advisory board, consisting of representatives of 
the fund investors with commitments of at least $20 million. The fund manager will exercise its 
discretion in inviting certain fund investors with capital commitments of less than $20 million to 
be also represented on the advisory board. The advisory board will represent the interests of the 
investors, and advise and provide guidance to the fund manager on matters related to fund 
operations, governance, and conflicts of interest. ADB will have a seat on the advisory board. 
 
20.  Investment committee. The fund will establish an investment committee to review and 
make decisions on the acquisition and divestment of proposed investments. The fund manager 
will not pursue any investments or cause the fund to enter into any transaction in the event of a 
negative recommendation by the investment committee. The committee will consist of one 
independent member other than the UOBVM investment professionals. To avoid any potential 
conflicts of interest, the independent member of the investment committee will have veto rights 
over investment approvals. 
 
3.  Risk Management 
21.  For private equity funds, risk management can be understood as the process by which 
the fund in question selects, analyzes, structures, and exits investments, i.e., the investment 
process and policies that aim to identify risks, balance those risks against the anticipated 
returns of the investment, and mitigate the risks to the extent possible. A key element in

by the fund manager.  
 
22.  Investment process. The investment process used for ACIF I has been refined over the 
past several years, while retaining the disciplines that have proven successful. This proven 
investment process will be used for this fund. The investment process can be briefly described 
as follows: (i) deal sourcing, (ii) an exploratory memo seeking approval of the management of 
UOBVM, (iii) investment opportunity due diligence, (iv) investment appraisal for the investment 
committee, and (v) fund manager's approval.  
 
23.  Investment policies. The fund manager also has a set of policies that it uses to screen 
and structure investments. The fund will carry out fundamental research and due diligence on 
each portfolio company in order to understand its objectives, management philosophies, and the 
personalities involved. The fund manager will seek to help its investee companies monitor 
market trends and product technology, not only through its own resources but also with the 
assistance of entrepreneurs, consultants, and industry experts. The fund will (i) seek to invest in 
SMEs  that  are  financially  sound,  with  solid  operating  performance,  profitability,  and  asset 
quality;  (ii) have  committed  senior  management  teams;  (iii)  have  an  attractive growth  and 
competitive position; and (iv) have a clear path to exit. The fund's portfolio companies must be 
well positioned to take advantage of interregional trade. The fund manager will also require the 
fund's portfolio companies to fully comply with national and international anti-money-laundering 
and  know-your-client  requirements.  These  policies  represent  additional  mechanisms  of 
mitigating risk beyond the investment process.  
 
 
C.  Business Overview and Strategy 
24.  Overview.  The  fund  will  invest  in  privately  negotiated  equity  and  equity-related 
investments in growth-oriented SMEs operating in the PRC and the ASEAN region. The fund 
will  actively  target  growth-oriented  medium-sized  companies  seeking  capital  to  finance 
expansion, acquisitions, joint ventures, or corporate restructuring. The fund will focus on sectors 
that are well positioned in terms of competitiveness and growth prospects and on investments 
likely to benefit from increased intra- and interregional trade. 
 
25.  Strategy. The fund will make investments of $5 million–$20 million per company, and 
will tend to take a minority equity stake (i.e., less than 50% in portfolio companies), which it will 
hold for an average of 3–5 years. The fund investments will generally take the form of ordinary 
or preference shares, convertible or exchangeable bonds, or debt with warrants. The fund will 
have board of directors representation and/or observer status, and veto power over major 
aspects of the portfolio company's business via a comprehensive shareholder agreement.  
 
26.  The targeted allocation for the fund is 50% in the ASEAN region and 50% in the PRC. 
The  targeted  suballocation  for  the  ASEAN  region  is  5%–10%  for  Cambodia  and  the  Lao 
People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), 25% for Viet Nam, 15%–20% for Thailand, 20%–30% 
for  Indonesia,  15%–20%  for  the  Philippines,  and  10%  for  Singapore. 10  The  targeted 
suballocation in the PRC is 20%–35% for the western region (Gansu, Guangxi, Guizhou, Inner

31.  Value  addition.  The fund manager will provide portfolio companies with access to 
management know-how, new markets, and new technology in addition to financing. Consistent 
with this approach, the manager will endeavor through its bank parent and/or other related 
corporations  to  help  portfolio  companies  obtain  new  funding  facilities,  prepare  portfolio 
companies for public listing, recruit a qualified financial controller, perform environment and 
social safeguards risk mitigation, improve corporate governance, and introduce the portfolio 
companies to analysts and institutional investors during the initial public offering (IPO). Value 
addition will also take the form of instituting consistent financial reporting, portfolio management, 
asset  quality,  nonperforming  loan  resolution,  budgeting,  and  planning  across  investee 
institutions.  
 
32.  Exit. The fund aims to exit investments over an average period of 3–5 years. UOBVM's 
experience  in  Asian  private  equity  since  1992  has  demonstrated  its  expertise  in  exiting

36.  ADB proposes to make an equity investment of up to $25 million in the fund, not to

the largest investor in the fund. ADB's equity contribution to the fund will be used exclusively for

fund will be 2.25% of the committed capital (in the event the committed capital for the fund

investment amounts thereafter. After returning all the investment amounts and an 8% per 
annum preferred return to fund investors, the fund manager will receive 25% of the preferred

achievement of 8% preferred return.

member states. ADB will make available its services to help identify and assess

C.  Risks and Mitigation Measures 
39.   The main risks of the investment and their principal mitigants are outlined below: 
 
(i)  Investment strategy. The investment environment has changed markedly from 
the time of the predecessor fund and the use of the same investment strategy for 
this follow-on fund may be unsuitable. In response, the fund manager has made 
several important changes to its investment strategy, specifically as regard to the 
geographic focus. The first fund invested heavily in the PRC and in a limited 
number of ASEAN countries. The second fund will target a wider basket of 
ASEAN countries including the Mekong Subregion and the Philippines. It will also 
broaden  its  coverage  of  the  PRC  to  include  the  relatively  underdeveloped 
western, central and northeastern regions. This change of focus should improve 
the investment prospects of the fund.  
 
(ii)  Competition for investments and deal pipeline risk. There is a risk that the 
success of the predecessor fund could lead to greater competition from other 
fund  managers  following  similar  strategies  and  targeting  the  same  types  of 
investments as this fund. Competition for investments may result in overvaluation 
of target investee companies and the loss of investment opportunities available to 
the fund. Companies listed in the pipeline of prospective investees may turn out 
to be unsuitable for reasons previously unidentified. This risk is partially mitigated 
by the abundant need for equity investment in the economies within the target 
region and by the fund manager's deep relationships in the market, which should 
facilitate the sourcing and development of pipeline opportunities going forward.   
 
(iii)  Insufficient management resources. Since the fund manager oversees other 
private  equity  funds  affiliated  with  the  sponsor,  the  availability  of  sufficient 
management  oversight  on  the  fund's  investment  activities  is  an  important 
consideration. This risk is mitigated by the pre-determined time commitment from 
each of the fund manager's key business executives. Furthermore, the advisory 
agreement and the partnership agreement designate key business executives for 
the  investment  adviser  and  general  partners  whose  continued  presence  is 
required  for  the  fund's  operation.  Their  absence  would  result  in  temporary 
suspension  of  the  fund's  investment  activities  until  it  is  remedied  by  the 
appointment of qualified replacements and lifting of suspension by the limited 
partners.   
 
(iv)  Potential conflicts of interest. The fund manager oversees other private equity 
funds affiliated with the sponsor. There is, therefore, potential conflict of interest 
from competition among affiliated funds for the same investment opportunities.  
This risk is modest as the timing for this fund differs from other sister funds, 
which are presently in exit phase, thereby preventing competition between funds

11
for  similar  investment  opportunities.  The  risk  of  this  fund  serving  as  an  exit 
mechanism for other affiliated funds is also minimal as this fund is prohibited from 
investing in companies owned by affiliates without prior approval of the advisory 
board,  whose  members  consist  of  representatives  from  the  limited  partners.  
Conflict of interest during investment phase is further controlled by the presence 
of one independent investment committee member who has veto power over 
decisions of the committee and whose selection is subject to ADB's right of "no 
objection". Finally, all banking and finance or advisory services will be awarded 
on an arm's length basis to ensure no exclusivity with UOB.   
 
(v)  Exit risks. The fund may experience difficulty exiting from investments within the 
planned divestment period. Valuations in the equities market may be too low for 
the fund to list its investment companies or to profitably exercise its conversion 
option after listing. This risk is partially mitigated by the fund manager obtaining 
put options at the time of purchase, where possible, and also by the policy of the 
fund manager to identify and arrange exit mechanisms at the time of investment. 
The fund manager's track record of successful exits in the predecessor fund 
should also mitigate this risk to some extent.  
 
(vi)  Currency risks. As the fund will be capitalized in US dollars and as specific 
investments  are  funded  in  the  local  currency,  the  fund  may  be  exposed  to 
currency depreciation in the countries of investment. This risk can be minimized 
through diversification of investments across the different countries of ASEAN.   
 
(vii)  Geopolitical, macroeconomic and social risks. The fund's investments will be 
in developing countries that are exposed to political, economic and social risks. 
These  risks  may  impact  the  returns  and  stability  of  the  fund’s  investments. 
However,  a  diversified  portfolio  approach  is  expected  to  mitigate  particular 
scenario risk from any one country. Furthermore, ADB’s bilateral linkages and 
close relationship with the governments in the region, which are seen to be 
supportive of prioritizing private sector development and other poverty reduction 
measures, may help mitigate these risks.   
 
(viii)  Accounting  and  disclosure  standards.  Accounting,  financial  and  other 
reporting  standards  in  many  developing  countries  in  Southeast  Asia  are  not 
equivalent to those in the United States and certain Western European countries.  
Accordingly, less information may be available to investors. These risks may be 
mitigated  by  requiring  that  the  fund  employ  international  financial  reporting 
standards and international standards on audit in the reports it submits to ADB, 
and through legal documentation that takes into consideration and mitigates the 
aforementioned risks as appropriate. 
 
(ix)  Legal risk and regulatory risk.  Different DMC governments impose varying 
legal requirements for investment entities like private equity funds. Because of 
undeveloped  or  underdeveloped  regulatory  frameworks  in  most  developing 
Southeast Asian countries, many laws and regulations are being changed or 
amended from time to time, which to varying degrees can negatively affect future 
investments of the fund. This risk is mitigated by a careful assessment of the 
legal environment by the fund manager and by legal documentation for fund 
investments that takes such risks into consideration. The fund manager, as part

12 
of its due diligence for fund investments, will retain external counsel to conduct 
legal due diligence.

41.  In keeping with implementation arrangements for the majority of ADB's private equity

environmental and social performance report. ADB will review these reports on an ongoing 
basis, alongside information on the portfolio's valuation and performance of individual investees. 
ADB will also be entitled to representation on the advisory board (i.e., the fund's governance 
body, separate from the board of directors), and via that representation will be involved in 
discussions and decisions related to corporate governance, portfolio valuations, and conflicts of 
interest.

15.   EHSLG screening and monitoring is an integral part of the ACIF risk management 
program. In this regard, the EHSLG provides a mechanism to assist the ACIF general partner to

recommendation is made to the general partner’s board of directors for a final decision, subject

action plans, and other measures, as well as requirements to submit environmental and social 
monitoring reports, will be included in the legal agreements with the investee company.

SMEs in ASEAN and the PRC; (ii) environmentally sustainable development, by screening and monitoring all 
investee companies for compliance with ADB, World Bank, and International Labor Organization environmental and 
social guidelines, and for compliance with best practices in respect of corporate governance; and (iii) regional 
integration, by contributing to the expansion of regional trade and investment between the ASEAN member states 
and the PRC, and their respective overseas trading partners.
